trans-unit.source: Exposes a stream around an anonymous pipe, which supports both synchronous and asynchronous read and write operations.
Anonymous pipes help provide safe and secure interprocess communication between child and parent processes.
The AnonymousPipeServerStream class enables a parent process to send or receive information from a child process.
Anonymous pipes are unnamed, one-way pipes that typically transfer data between parent and child processes.
Anonymous pipes are always local; they cannot be used over a network.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.
Anonymous pipes do not support <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode> read modes.
The client side of an anonymous pipe must be created from a pipe handle provided by the server side by calling the <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream.GetClientHandleAsString%2A> method.
The string is then passed as a parameter when creating the client process.
From the client process, it is then passed to the <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream> constructor as the `pipeHandleAsString` parameter.

The AnonymousPipeServerStream object must dispose the client handle using the <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream.DisposeLocalCopyOfClientHandle%2A> method in order to be notified when the client exits.
> [!NOTE] > For [!INCLUDE[winxppro](~/add/includes/winxppro-md.md)] and [!INCLUDE[win2kserver](~/add/includes/win2kserver-md.md)], a maximum of 10 pipes can simultaneously connect over the network.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> class.
For <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> constructors without a <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> parameter, the default direction is <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection>.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.

This constructor creates an <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object that has the default buffer size, no pipe security, and a <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability> value of <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability>.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> class with the specified pipe direction.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.

This constructor creates an <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object that has the default buffer size, no pipe security, and a <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability> value of <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability>.
One of the enumeration values that determines the direction of the pipe.
Anonymous pipes can only be in one direction, so `direction` cannot be set to <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection"></xref>.
direction is set to .
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> class with the specified pipe direction and inheritability mode.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.
This constructor creates an <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object that has the default buffer size and no pipe security.
One of the enumeration values that determines the direction of the pipe.
Anonymous pipes can only be in one direction, so `direction` cannot be set to <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection"></xref>.
One of the enumeration values that determines whether the underlying handle can be inherited by child processes.
Must be set to either <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability> or <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability>.
inheritability is not set to either or .
direction is set to .
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> class from the specified pipe handles.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.
One of the enumeration values that determines the direction of the pipe.
Anonymous pipes can only be in one direction, so `direction` cannot be set to <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection"></xref>.
A safe handle for the pipe that this <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> object will encapsulate.
A safe handle for the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream"></xref> object.
serverSafePipeHandle or clientSafePipeHandle is an invalid handle.
serverSafePipeHandle or clientSafePipeHandle is .
direction is set to .
An I/O error, such as a disk error, has occurred.
-or- The stream has been closed.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> class with the specified pipe direction, inheritability mode, and buffer size.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.
This constructor creates an <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object without pipe security.
One of the enumeration values that determines the direction of the pipe.
Anonymous pipes can only be in one direction, so `direction` cannot be set to <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection"></xref>.
One of the enumeration values that determines whether the underlying handle can be inherited by child processes.
Must be set to either <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability> or <xref:System.IO.HandleInheritability>.
The size of the buffer.
This value must be greater than or equal to 0.
inheritability is not set to either or .
-or- bufferSize is less than 0.
direction is set to .
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> class with the specified pipe direction, inheritability mode, buffer size, and pipe security.
A <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> value of <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection> is not supported because anonymous pipes are defined to be one-way.
One of the enumeration values that determines the direction of the pipe.
Anonymous pipes can only be in one direction, so `direction` cannot be set to <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeDirection"></xref>.
One of the enumeration values that determines whether the underlying handle can be inherited by child processes.
The size of the buffer.
This value must be greater than or equal to 0.
An object that determines the access control and audit security for the pipe.
inheritability is not set to either or .
-or- bufferSize is less than 0.
direction is set to .

Gets the safe handle for the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream"></xref> object that is currently connected to the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> object.
The <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream.DisposeLocalCopyOfClientHandle%2A> method should be called after a client handle has been passed to a client process.
If this method is not called, the <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object will not receive notice when the client disposes of its <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeStream> object.
A handle for the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream"></xref> object that is currently connected to the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> object.
To be added.
Closes the local copy of the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream"></xref> object's handle.
The DisposeLocalCopyOfClientHandle method should be called after the client handle has been passed to the client.
If this method is not called, the <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object will not receive notice when the client disposes of its <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeStream> object.
Releases unmanaged resources and performs other cleanup operations before the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> instance is reclaimed by garbage collection.
Gets the connected <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream"></xref> object's handle as a string.
The <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream.DisposeLocalCopyOfClientHandle%2A> method should be called after a client handle has been passed to a client process.
If this method is not called, the <xref:System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream> object will not receive notice when the client disposes of its <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeStream> object.
A string that represents the connected <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeClientStream"></xref> object's handle.
Sets the reading mode for the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> object.
For anonymous pipes, transmission mode must be <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode"></xref>.
Anonymous pipes do not support <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode> read mode.
The reading mode for the <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.AnonymousPipeServerStream"></xref> object.
The transmission mode is not valid.
For anonymous pipes, only <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode"></xref> is supported.
The property is set to <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode"></xref>, which is not supported for anonymous pipes.
The connection is broken or another I/O error occurs.
The pipe is closed.
Gets the pipe transmission mode that is supported by the current pipe.
Anonymous pipes do not support <xref:System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode> read mode.
The <xref href="System.IO.Pipes.PipeTransmissionMode"></xref> that is supported by the current pipe.
